commentBody:
On the same page with gangi and all of those letters. 

New personal best on wednesdays for me.  Thanks, pal. 

I‚Äôm guessing tomorrow we are going to get spanked with a rebus. I found the most maniacal rebus in the archives, July 4, 2004. Took me over an hour to complete it.  I‚Äôm looking forward to tomorrows punishment
Another good one! Thanks!
Fun! Seems more like a Monday puzzle?

Sam,

Re: 62 Across
You don't need a garage.
In an auto race, the cars make a PIT stop to retire.
A gentle theme and a pleasant puzzle.  Perfectly cromulent.
This might be the easiest Wednesday I've ever done in my life?? 4m 34s. No hints or anything. I loved the clues and the theme but I tore through this. My W average is like 9-10.
This puzzle was so much fun. Clues were perfectly clever: not too easy, not too obscure - snd the theme was "gettable" with some thinking.

"What's the ATOMICMASS of SALSA? Never mind, it's an INSIDEJOKE" ;)

The MUSIC of 17A and -ZU- of 14A mean I keep misreading 5D (in finished grid) as SUzuki..

New Weds PB, almost as fast as yesterday (by 11s), and generally quite enjoyable. I'm happy with it, anyway!

I was seriously concerned about 5D.  Six letters for [Perform dreadfully, so to speak], and I had the _UCK__

I really thought for a moment we were going to start a new era in NYT crosswords.

Really, I thought for sure it was going to be something obscene like MUCKUP.

A clue like 49D "Overwhelmingly busy" for hectic doesn't merely use an extra word when just "Busy" works just fine. It actually *misleads*, but not in a enjoyable way. The word hectic means rather busy, indeed, but has nothing to do with anything "overwhelming".

I‚Äôm having a faint memory of a puzzle that exploited the fact that LA is a musical note, a chemical symbol, and a postal code.

Am I just making that up - anyone remember?

I think [Periodic __] would have been a great clue for TABLE. I enjoyed all of the different ways the theme letters had things in common, but also unique from each other. Tight theme. Thank you, Joseph. 

Happy hump day, crosslandia üê™
very fun puzzle, but probably too easy for a wednesday

Really lively theme with good misdirection in the clues. 

Nice job and thank you, Joseph!

Great puzzle and a very fun theme!

I think it's PIT as in the NASCAR stop for new tires, versus the sunken spot in a garage which is for oil changes.

So, I‚Äôll put my hand up with the current and future commentators who think it was a little easy for a Wednesday. That said I thought the theme was very entertaining and the other two longer entries were interesting (I noticed that even before I saw the constructor‚Äôs note). The other shorter entries were pretty unremarkable (I did like PIT though). I was amused by IMON right above LINE (I imagine an understudy finally getting their chance and then getting nervous). Finally a shout out to puzzle construction‚Äîit‚Äôs not easy to have two down theme entries that cross a theme entry going through the middle, that are all as smooth as this one. So give credit where credit is due and don‚Äôt get hung up if you think the general puzzle is too easy.

I appreciated the misdirection; it caused a few re-typed entries, although most of the puzzle was pretty straightforward and filled in readily.

Thanks, Joseph!

M, T and W have been as easy as ABC this week.

Heres hoping for a sinister Thursday!

‚ÄúIf we shadows have offended,
‚ÄÉThink but this, and all is mended--
‚ÄÉThat you have but slumbered here
‚ÄÉWhile these visions did appear.
‚ÄÉAnd this weak and idle theme,
‚ÄÉNo more yielding but a dream,
‚ÄÉGentles, do not reprehend.
‚ÄÉIf you pardon, we will mend.
‚ÄÉAnd, as I am an honest Puck,
‚ÄÉIf we have unearn√®d luck
‚ÄÉNow to ‚Äôscape the serpent‚Äôs tongue,
‚ÄÉWe will make amends ere long.
‚ÄÉElse the Puck a liar call.
‚ÄÉSo good night unto you all.
‚ÄÉGive me your hands if we be friends,
‚ÄÉAnd Robin shall restore amends.‚Äù
Curious if Mr Gangi was extending an apology if he offended us in anyway by making this quote the second to last clue of the puzzle. Big fan of this monologue. Loved music notes and chemical symbols. Think I might need to memorize the characters of the office as it was my one hang up

Enjoyed this puzzle.  My fave clue was¬†‚Äúplace to retire‚Äù. 

I an getting closer and closer to remembering what a cryptid is. And I always enjoy a little Ogden Nash. Do they teach old songs like The Erie Canal any more in schools?

Thanks for a pleasant Wednesday puzzle!
Finished it with a new personal best, 8:15! I feel each of the themed clues were part of separate crosswords in past
roommate and i throughly enjoyed. be careful though, 6 down is only true with units of amu!
Loved it. No sports, no foreign words, only one college abbreviation and it was an easy one, and very few proper nouns.
Really enjoyable with lots of fun cluing.
Relaxing but fun puzzle.

I‚Äôm either getting better or this was easier than most Wednesdays. I used zero clues and did it almost 6 mins faster than my average. 

Definitely enjoyed it. Cute little theme.
Joseph, I really enjoyed your lovely it puzzle and most likely would have gotten your origin Al clue for 51-down [Periodic ___] much sooner than the one used today. Thanks! Elizabeth

Immensely enjoyable, with a great theme and on point cluing. Thank you, Mr. Gangi! . . . Here's ASIA with "Only Time Will Tell" (and hopefully it doesn't take EONS...) https://youtu.be/AWs8SbT4__E?si=cZCXv2ACPliEq4D5
Perfect Wednesday puzzle.

I ended with the NE corner and broke out in song upon completion‚Ä¶

low bridge, everybody down, 
low bridge cuz we‚Äôre coming to a town, 
and you‚Äôll always know your neighbor, 
you‚Äôll always know your pal, 
if you‚Äôve ever navigated on the Erie Canal. 

And I did!  Early 2000‚Äôs, Seneca Falls to Rockport in a 42 foot steel hulled canal boat. It think it was 16 locks we went through. 

When a crossword puzzle throws you into good memories‚Ä¶.

Thanks.
I really enjoyed this one. I even liked the gimmick, which I rarely do.

Another buggy day. I finished, got my gold star to continue my streak, and when I looked later, it says I never finished, the counter is still going, and I can't reveal puzzle or make any changes. 

Second time in maybe a month or so that this bug has ruined my gold star streak.

A letterally satisfying puzzle, with some CATCHy clues.   My puzzlement about the INSIDEJOKE only LASTED briefly (actually, I TORE through the whole thing pretty quickly).  

You're saying I INEPTly mined the grid for a few NIeCE comment words?  Well, what will you say if ISUZU?

For those that have started doing the Midi Crossword this week...where is it actually located? I can't find it anywhere. The only way I can access it, is to click on the link from the original email (Monday), and then change the URL to suit today's date. Surely there has to be a direct link for Games subscribers, either on the website or the app, or both. Thanks.

I found the puzzle a bit of a let down. To me this felt and solved like a Tuesday (judging by my time), and a themeless one, too. There was nothing wrong with it, really, and yet it personally did not feel fun or interesting ü§∑. I know there was a theme, in a way, but the "themed" entries were loosely connected - just by the letter/abbreviation thing... Oh, and, the grid looks a bit messy, doesn't it? I generally pay no attention to that but I was just poring over the filled grid, desperately looking for something interesting or nice to say about it, and that's what I got in stead...

The NW corner would have been problematic for me had I not known the Japanese car brand. I only vaguely remembered the name of the guy from Harry Potter - I never got into the books or films.

My dog and best friend of 14 years, Benny, is going in for major surgery tomorrow (Wednesday). He has a 6 cm liver mass, statistically likely to be hepatocellular carcinoma (doggy liver cancer). He was a stray when we got him, so I have no idea how old he is. And it may seem cruel and selfish to do surgery on an old dog, but just yesterday he was out sprinting me like he did all those years ago. The vet says that with surgery, he likely has a  few more years (without surgery, months). 

Yes, I knew that this day would come eventually. But it's never easy. I haven't been able to focus at work, and so had to cancel my week. All I can think about is my best friend, and the great times we've had, and how he carried me when it was just me and him for years.

That is all I can think about... Besides when the next crossword is going to drop. Stupid streak.
For a while I wondered what gene rations were.

Given Sam Corbin‚Äôs warning on Monday:

 ‚ÄúMay it brace us all for the uncertainty of the solving week ahead‚Äú 

and how Tuesday and Wednesday have gone,  I‚Äôm predicting some sort of cataclysmic puzzling to come later this week. 

They‚Äôre building up to something.
First time I completed a Wednesday without looking at the wordplay column or using any cheats!
Enjoyed this, and very smooth for a Wednesday. Serendipitously, I got PIT by an alternative definition in British English: a slang word for "bed". A perfect way to retire (and never re-tyre)

While a PIT *is* a sunken bay in a car repair shop, Sam, you would never change a tire in or from one.  You re-tire a race car in the PIT at a racetrack. Who knows, it's etymology might spring from the pit in a garage, though.
Really fun and great theme. PB for a Wednesday for us.

Delightful! And a brag: I finished it (in 24:36) without using any of the Down clues ‚Äî I only looked at the Acrosses. By my reckoning that mashes it an excellent puzzle, and perhaps slightly easy, but I‚Äôm not complaining!
Just right for a Wednesday which are often either too easy or difficult (for me anyway) .  Well done, Joseph.

Any puzzle that starts with Dumbledore is ok with me.
Got the theme early with 17A, but it took a while to work out the rest. I‚Äôm ashamed to say that I thought GENE RATIONS was a perfectly good answer, given that I‚Äôm completely scientifically illiterate. I‚Äôll get my coat.
Fun solve before coffee (or getting out of bed). Monday, Tuesday, and today have all been well below my average times. I'm hoping tomorrow will be a bit tougher.

(You‚Äôve got a couple extra letters in your 17A answer here! Should just be MUSICNOTES, although fwiw I agree, the term flows off the tongue more easily with that extra syllable.)

Really enjoyed this puzzle! Not too easy, but also not too hard. Wednesdays and Thursdays are usually the trickiest for me, something about the more obscure clues and often being themeless. Thanks so much Joseph!
I vibed so much with the constructor that it felt like a Monday. Lovely puzzle and a new Wednesday best time!

Did anyone else go down a few dead ends? I had ‚Äúexam passes‚Äù and ‚Äútest scores‚Äù before MUSICALNOTES and I was convinced the word ‚Äúelements‚Äù was somewhere in the He & I answer, until a few letters of CHEMICAL began to point in another direction, and eventually SYMBOLS came to me. 

Kudos to the setter for giving clues that were obviously tricksy, but with multiple avenues of misadventure, none more credible than the final correct answer.

Those with longer memories, or better resources, could tell me, but it's my feeling that all of these clues have appeared before, as punny clues in Friday or Saturday puzzles--I know the [He and I] one has. Still, among my favorite *types* of clue! Brief memo from the Dept. of the Nittery: NOTES vs. tones vs. pitches (or even "pitch classes")--technically different concepts, but close enough for Crosslandia, or Joseph II: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AUFwk1Ibwkc Don't forget: Nothing Compares 2 Uranium: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_ZlzN0Gtpp8&list=RD_ZlzN0Gtpp8&start_radio=1

Bore up=LASTED?
I don't quite see the connection.
As in, "I don't know how I lasted all the way through "Cats" the movie" ?
Anyone else notice that the actual Wordplay column is getting shorter and shorter? It‚Äôs starting to feel really phoned in. Interesting to compare recent columns to ones from 5+ years ago.

I thought mass was in grams, after someone‚Äôs frantic pedantic rant last week. So for ‚Äúfigure‚Äù I figured ATOMIC MATH, until the crosses didn‚Äôt fit, which made me say ATOMIC wait‚Ä¶


I‚Äôm not in the US, and I got 32D, so there!

I was going to do this one last night but it was time to re-tire.  

(Whether INSIDE or outside, my JOKEs are the PITs)

Sorry Mike.  

Ignored the NW corner so finished up there with a TIL on both ALBUS and ISUZU. 

Breezy fun. Thanks.

Sam in your column on solving the puzzle ‚Äîin  17A 
it‚Äôs  ‚Äúmusic notes‚Äù. Not  ‚Äúmusical notes‚Äù.  
Thank for your column!

I'll join the chorus (daddy sings bass). Good long workout for me but a really clever theme and an enjoyable workout. Answer history search today was for CHEMICALSYMBOLS. It's appeared in two other puzzles and was a part of a clever (and unusual) theme in both of them. One of those was a Tuesday from August 30, 2016 by Roland Huget. It was the 'reveal' in that puzzle with the clue: "This puzzle's circled letters, for the words that precede them" Some examples of the answers: COPPER(CU)PS IRON(FE)NCE SILVER(AG)E And the other puzzle was a Monday from October 2, 2017 by Trenton Charlson. The clue for it in that puzzle was: "B C F H I K N O P S U V W Y " And some other clues and answers: "A B C D E F G" MUSICNOTES "G R X" MOVIERATINGS "A B O" BLOODTYPES and... "B C F H I K N O P S U V W Y" CHEMICALSYMBOLS Here's the Xword Info link for that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/2/2017&g=39&d=A I'm done. ...

I've certainly already seen references to Gen A, also denoted Generation Alpha. Editorial choice there, to keep the paired clues at the expense of a bit of accuracy.

Got the theme with POSTALCODES, which was probably my favorite thematic entry. The clue for CHEMICALSYMBOLS was also clever, but by then I already knew the theme so that one was easy.

MUSICNOTES continues to sound forced to me---as in, forced to occupy ten boxes in order to pair symmetrically with BLOODTYPES.

Decent Wednesday puzzle, but seemed rather "gentle" to me.

Didn't have much trouble with this one. A nice way to glide into the rest of the week.
Creative theme!

Special place in my heart for Joseph Gangi, today‚Äôs constructor, because he made the cutest-looking puzzle I‚Äôve ever seen, no exaggeration; I‚Äôm smiling in my heart just thinking about it. You owe yourself a look: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2022/03/16 . My favorite part of today‚Äôs puzzle was the riddles ‚Äì trying to guess the theme answers from their clues alone, not even looking at the crosses (the theme was clear after getting the first theme answer). I come into the box hoping to satisfy my brain‚Äôs work ethic, and this did that for me. Oh, I liked the three palindromes (EWE, LIL, EXE) and the cross of words that sound like letters (CEE, ESSAY), but I loved the riddles. Joseph must have seriously happy-danced when he saw that CHEMICAL SYMBOLS could be crossed in just the right places by POSTAL CODES and GENERATIONS. A just reward for those uncountable times in a constructor‚Äôs experience when things don‚Äôt turn out that way. And Joseph, you brought my heart and brain a lovely reward today as well ‚Äì thank you!

RE:62D---
I'm retired, so I can attest that it can be the "PITS".
But, i challenge the term "PIT" to mean a site in a car shop where tires are changed. That's where jobs like changing the engine oil, but in my decades buying tires I've never known the work to be done below ground level. IMHO it's always done with the vehicle slightly elevated, so the old ones can be easily pulled off the lugs, to be rolled over to the special stand where each tire in turn is removed from the rim, and the new tire is installed. Then the newbies are rolled over to their places on the car. 

Some alternative clues to consider:

1. Poe's place for a pendulum. [His short story "The Pit and the Pendulum"]
2. Place for bad stomach vibes. [e.g., "bad feeling in the pit of my stomach"]
3. What a drupe contains. [A "drupe" is a type of fruit, such as a peach or plum -- any fruit with a central seed, the "PIT"]

That was fun! I have bested my average every day this week - today‚Äôs was 17:20 faster than my average (though somehow not my PB) - and I have a four-Wednesday streak going! I love the abbreviation theme. It‚Äôs interesting that A, B, C and X, Y, Z could be used two different ways. I‚Äôm hoping the easy week continues but I‚Äôm not holding my breath!

Fun, but 17a was a bit weird. The column refers to the answer as "musical notes," but the actual answer was "music notes." Not sure what gives, but I hesitated since it seemed off given that "music" was an adjective and not a noun.
Ok credit for at least a somewhat creative way to get ‚Äúeels‚Äù in there, it comes up so often must be hard to find new ways to spin the clues.

Apparently, this one gets a bit into the weeds from a constructing strategy standpoint. Regardless, from a solving standpoint, it is straightforward and enjoyable. Are we burdening our beloved constructor community with too many nerdy conventions, perhaps? Only Noam Chomsky can tell.

Fun breezy puzzle. In his notes Joseph refers to 32D (INSIDEJOKE) as a non-theme answer. I'd say it's semi-theme, as the theme clues are all in a style that long-time solvers recognize, and still chuckle at. 

I've been stumped before by the contronym 51D (TABLE), which has opposite meanings in British and US English (Canadians go with the Brits on this one).  Although maybe it's not a true contronym since it depends on the speaker and not the context -- I don't know what else to call it.

I thought "pit" as a place to retire in terms of racing, where a car might need to drop out of the race after going to the pit if there are substantial issues. 

Fun solve! When filling in the last few squares I was sad that it was coming to an end.

It must have been fun to come up with these lists and the tricky clues.  It was certainly fun to solve!  That is....Except for the "Sch. On the banks of the Mississippi...." 
 It's a very long river with a lot of Universities (starting with Minnesota) nearby...  and crossing it with a Harry Potter character was a bit unfair.  The first book came out a Looooong time ago.  

Gangi is an interesting name!

Could someone please help me with how CEE is a "tragic ending?" I think this is the only one I didn't understand. 

Had NAG (at) as "EAT" (at) and "TES" (as in "Rockettes") instead of EER ("rocketeer"), until I finally got NEICE, so that area gave me the most trouble. 

Really liked the riddles and the puzzle today!
I understand that you would RE-TIRE in a pit but I had a good chuckle at the idea of retiring to a pit. Get in the pit!
Another breezy puzzle. So far this week I fell two seconds shy of my best on Monday, and set new bests yesterday and today.
uh oh. 10m Wednesday puzzle...conspiracies will rise...

Zipped on through, and enjoyed the theme. Happy Wednesday!
(Had to finish yesterday's Bee before I could enjoy today's offerings. I only work it up to Genius, and also require myself to get the pangram, and I was just STUCK on needing it to be "bioethic", despite knowing it wasn't. Does that ever happen to anyone? BIOTECH was my last entry.)

That was quite a photo for today's column! I can't find a definitive answer as to when they sold their first million burgers, seems to be around 1952. Maybe someone who knows automobiles can date the photo from the cars. 

And maybe someone who knows photography can say something about the photo itself? Mr. Simon?

Kodachrome
They give us those nice bright colors
They give us the greens of summers
Makes you think all the world‚Äôs
A sunny day, oh yeah

One nit about 43A. I found there is such a word as rocketEER but I'm thinking there may be a typo in the clue as racket would be a lot better.

Nothing more. I see we're all clear on pit.
I don‚Äôt understand how ‚ÄúBore up‚Äù is lasted ?
Really cute theme! Maybe a *mite* too easy for a Wednesday, but fun nonetheless.

I stumbled around a bit with clue 43 across(suffix with rocket), first picking "man", then finally only "eer" fit.  Looking it up, I find I was way in the wrong generation.  Otherwise, easy and cute.  Being a chemist, two clues were especially fun for me.
When I saw 51D, I knew that might cause some agita for our British friends, where the verb TABLE means the opposite of what it does here.
Clever puzzle. Well done!

Excellent & fun puzzle. Funny how some entire puzzles seem to just be in our ‚Äúwheelhouse,‚Äù as today‚Äôs was for me. While others (Monday‚Äôs) almost seem alien ‚Äî to me, that is. 

Have a lovely day. If you‚Äôre in the N Y City area, enjoy another day of gentler weather!
Is there an error in Sam's article?  The article says 17A is "MUSICAL NOTE" but I completed my puzzle with "MUSIC NOTES". Musical Note doesn't even fit.
"Place to retire" made me think of F1 racing, where drivers sometimes have to retire their cars in the pit.

I just loved this theme.  There aren't many puzzles that induce me to show my husband the puzzle as soon as he comes down in the morning, but this was one.  

Easy?  Sure, but I never complain until Thursday. ; )

On Tuesday I barely remembered not to turn Autocheck on--I save that for Wed~Sun. Last night when I started today's puzzle I forgot to turn it on. But by the time I remembered it was going well enough that I decided not to.

Things I needed to do made me shut down the computer, but I finished up quickly (quickly for me nowadays = 30 minutes) when I got back to it this morning. It had been quite a while since I last got my streak up to 3!)

The misdirection in 11D was great! Since I'm not much of a Disney buff and only ever watched The Jungle Book as a kid, I had Shere Khan the TIGER for 49A. Seemed correct to me since POST GRAD DGS fits and matches the abbreviations.

But we got there eventually...
Loved it!
Where is the new MIDI crossword ?

I liked the theme, good fun, but a coupe of tricky clues for me.
There was TABLE, as mentioned already; and SUCK AT took me a while, even with the K,  (I don''t know any Harry Potter, or names of cars, and I don't have Netflix) because it's not a phrase I ever use. 

I was so wanting the cryptid to be 'haggis'!

Fantastic theme misdirects.   Even when I could swim around the answer of a themed clue, I always needed a good amount of crosses (e.g. MA and MS are states, abbreviations, initialisms,..   it took many acrosses before I realized Postal Codes).   Mentally I found it tough for a Wednesday, and yet I came in 50% faster than my Wednesday average.... Go figure. üòÅ
What a fun solve! I chopped 45 seconds off my previous best for a new Wednesday PR of 6:50. Lots of misdirects to keep things fun!

Not knowing Harry Potter and school locations very well I had to debate between Ambus and Albus. I guessed correctly. Others such has Atbus or Akbus didn't sound right.

p.s. I decided to let the Natick Police rest.
The answer the "x, y, and z but not a, b, or c" is wrong. Because Gen Alpha is now a thing. I was stuck on this
Loved the reveal today!

I posted this as a reply earlier, but it's buried and not obvious.

The picture is the McDonald's 1 Store Museum, and it was located at 400 Lee Street in Des Plaines, IL, just off of US 45. 

I say "was", because the site is now vacant in both Google Maps and Apple Maps.

I had gone by it  for the last time in either late 2022 or early 2023, before we moved south. It was always closed whenever I went by. If you look it up on Google Maps there are pictures that include covered cars that appear to be the ones in the picture.
I'll be honest, I like Mondays getting easier for beginners, but am not sure how I feel about this one. It feels like it might've even worked as a Tuesday (or is the theme a bit too weird for that?)

I'm always puzzled (har!) when I confidently enter an answer that I have no earthly idea why I know it, but it turns out correct. Today it was AMANDA. I've never watched Mean Girls and I don't even know what she looks like. (I could probably remedy that pretty quickly.) Anyhow, I  just find it interesting. I suppose it's some sort of cultural absorption that comes from being alive in a certain time and place. 

Now, ALBUS, on the other hand, a gimme ever since I fell in love with the books at the tender young age of 42.  ‚ö°üìú‚ö°

Here's another thing that puzzles me, on the midi (and thank you to Capt Q and others who've posted about it), why at the end are there two boxes whose borders turn green. Today it is an S and an O. Is there a reason for this that I'm missing?  NOIDEA!

Oh, but back to this puzzle, I thought it was good, quick fun! Though, like others, it took me just short of forrrrrr-evvvvvvvvvvv-errrrrrrrrrrrrrr to correctly parse GENERATIONS. It was all right there, but it was so hard for me to see. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 

Guess it's apt that it crossed INEPT.  üòâ
38A got me.

Chemist here. Of course I love all chemistry-related clues, but I take a small issue with 6-Down. The sum of protons plus neutrons is what we call the mass number and is specific to a particular isotope of an element. The atomic mass is typically understood to be a weighted average of the masses of all isotopes.  The mass number is always an integer, while the atomic mass generally is not. Not trying to be a buzz kill, just taking the opportunity to educate! I managed to get the answer anyway. ;)

I say again my extreme discouragement regarding the new crossword stats.

When I mentioned it yesterday, it was recommended at least 33 times, so other people found it worthwhile, and I thank those readers.

If I may be forgiven for using an almost sacred phrase, the problem has to do with ‚ÄúThe Fierce Urgency of Now‚Äù:

We really don‚Äôt care about how our puzzles stack up to other days, because the puzzles get harder each day.

We want the stats of NOW, ‚Äúhow did my solving stack up to other Wednesdays, in terms of AVERAGE, TODAY, and BEST?‚Äù

We don‚Äôt want to tap from screen to screen to see how Wednesday stacks up to Thursday, etc.

The way the stats used to be presented was able to show that AT A GLANCE.

I hope NYTGames will put the stats back like they were before,
Every once in a while, you get a puzzle that just sings. That's what this one was. Poifect.
A delightful mix of the arts and sciences - loved it!
This was fun. Thanks, Joseph Gangi.
What is this midi puzzle that I keep seeing folks reference? What am I missing? Help!
7:09 faster than average and not a lookup! Clues felt fresh and rewarding, plus my name was in there. All in all, perfect weds puzzle.

Ummmmm
Is it me or is the clue provided for 17A MUSIC NOTES not MUSICAL NOTES?!?!?

Sang along with Springsteen to Erie Canal (and all the other songs on The Seeger Sessions plus quite a few others) on the long drive home from Montreal to Toronto today -  kinda fabulous to see it turning up in the NYT crossword too!

Chiming in to say thank you, Joseph, this puzzle was delightful! Our wheelhouses appear to fit in the same sliver of a Venn diagram.

Loved the chemical symbols, state codes, blood types... Perfect amount of crunch.
Nice one, flowed great!

@Red Carpet

That was some crazy puzzle.

It took me a couple hours to get to the point I wasn't going to continue looking for errors.

I had one.  But wow!

@Francis

It was very memorable. I refused to give up.  And since it‚Äôs in the old format of not allowing the one letter substitute for the rebus, I had to keep working on it.

@Susan Avallon

No, not for me.
@Barry Ancona  Re-tire.
...and in the ones I've seen, the car's wheels straddle the garage PIT; to retire, you'll want a lift.

@Marshall Walthew

Cronut!

@Matthew S.

Same.  I shouldn‚Äôt be doing a Wednesday puzzle sub 5 minutes.  That was faster than my fastest Tuesday.  I also liked the theme and thought it was well constructed, but a Wednesday should give some resistance
@Andrew CRNA.  how do you all get so fast at them?   Dictionary studies?

@Francis

There will be pearl clutchers will consider the actual answer beneath appropriate decorum as well.
@SP I can remember when you just did not use that word that way in mixed company, in school and in front of one's family. Ever.

@Francis
That was my "at least one error." I decided that after all ALBUm was a nice word, but a lousy name.
@Francis I thought it was SUCK iT not AT. Fun puzzle. Gentle but I was thinking :)

@Dan

Agreed! 

Though by the time I reached that clue, I had 99% of the answer done, and HECTIC slid right in. 

To me, [Overwhelmingly busy] would solve to "insane". So I'm pretty lucky I don't solve bottom up!

@G

A fair nit

@Cat Lady Margaret

@Andrzej

I enjoyed 40A.  By that time I could see that some clues weren't saying what it looked like they were saying, so I realized He and I were the symbols for the elements helium and iodine.

As far as the grid looking messy, I dunno what a messy grid and what a neat grid looks like.

A billion years ago, when I was a teenager working in a newsroom, one of the things the national editor always charged with worrying about was the layout of the front page--whether it was pretty or not.

I could *never* see any difference.  And I was never able to find anyone who could explain the difference.

@Francis

I‚Äôm a bit burdened by living in that
minority and its headspace.

I look for balance.
Light and dark
should even each other out, and
bold print and photos on a menu
or newspaper page
can hurt my eyeballs when they 
aren‚Äôt placed intentionally.

With the grids, 
I always spend a moment
checking it out, wondering if it‚Äôs 
giving me hints.

And I far prefer left/right symmetry 
to rotational. 
Just prettier.

So I totes agree with Andrzej
(and I‚Äôm well aware that what I just
wrote begs the reader to ask if 
I‚Äôm in therapy, which I am).

@Francis

Regarding the beauty of grids (and front pages), I like to think of the art of Piet Mondrian.  If you've ever seen his work, I think you'll know what I mean.  Just a bunch of black lines, in a rectilinear formation, with a few patches of primary colors.  So simple.
But, they always (or almost always) look "right"; not too busy, not too boring; just satisfying.  A sense of order that makes you say, "Ahh."
He didn't work with a formula, so the sense of "rightness" can't really be explained, but if you get it, you get it.  (And if you don't,....)

@DocP
UPDATE!

Benny is out of surgery. The surgeon was able to completely resect the tumour. She said that he looks really really good for a 15 year old. We had a chance to see him post op, wearing the cone of shame. He was happy to see us. I fear we may have excited him too much. 

Poor Foxy, his best friend, has been waiting by the door, waiting for him to come home. I wish I could post pics. I'll post again with an update when he comes home tomorrow.

Thanks for the well wishes everyone. I have to think that the positive energy being sent his way have helped him so far.

@William Schrader

It's interesting to note, that before hydraulic lifts became universally available, mechanics dug PITs in the ground so that they could work underneath the car.  This is presumably where the term from auto racing comes from.
But since the car straddles the pit (in the ground or in the garage), it is of no use for changing tires.

@Mary. Yup of course‚Ä¶ note the ‚Äúroughly‚Äù in the clue.

But you bring up a key point and one of my favorites.  Originally atomic mass used in the 1800‚Äôs because that was what they could measure. Then hands on experiment by Moseley deduced unexpectedly that atomic number, which is the number of protons in the nucleus, was a better source of the causation of the pattern in the periodic table, and about the same time, isotopes of neon and then of other elements we‚Äôre unexpectedly discovered. 

Finally Einstein‚Äôs E=mc^2 finished the story of atomic mass, applied to the nuclear binding energy.

Terrific journey of understanding the atom and the nucleus.

@Mary

The terminology is tricky here, and maybe not as well-defined as it should, but...

The way I read it is that the mass number of any specific isotope of an element is the sum of protons and neutrons.

The weighted average is *molar mass*, or in older terms, the "atomic weight".
